I upgraded from the Samsung S8 to the Samsung S9+
I'm happy I decided to get the plus edition of the S9 as it offers a lot of extra features for the value in addition to higher quality components and screen size and resolution
But there's an expandable memory bay in the S9+ which allows you to add up to 1TB of storage
Unlocked is the way to go
I read all the reviews and decided to go with the Amazon shipped version of this phone to have the Amazon guarantee
A lot of reviews said this phone would not work on Verizon, and that voicemail and wireless calling was not going to work
My wireless calling works fine, my voicemail works fine and the phone works on Verizon
Here is what I discovered that you will need to do if you purchase this phone if you putting it on Verizon

Be sure to register an account with Samsung Galaxy store right on the phone and update all of your apps and when you do, it will give you Samsung Essentials and visual voicemail that is just like Verizon's only with a Blue Icon instead of Red
Works the same

If you go into the settings, and turn on wireless calling, it might take a couple of tries, but it does come on, and it does work as I live in a completely shielded home where Verizon's signal does not penetrate my walls or roof and my phone works perfectly over wireless
As far as getting connected to Verizon goes, all you have to do is take your SIM card from your old phone and put it in the new phone
If you have to get a new SIM card from Verizon because of size difference, have Verizon register a new SIM to your old phone, then you put it into the new phone

These phones are approved on Verizon's list of phones, but their system does not recognize the IMEI number and says it is not compatible and won't let the stores customer service reps scan the phone into their system
You have to put your old SIM into the new phone and then it works perfectly
I called 611 while I was in the store and they told me how to get around their system not recognizing the IMEI numbers as valid
The unlocked S9+ is the best phone I have ever had
Great phone, good battery life, cheaper than buying directly from Verizon.
My S7 Edge LCD screen just died last month so I needed a phone right away
In all honesty, I like the looks of the S7 Edge better than this S9

I'm happy with my first renewed purchase!I'll definitely consider it again so that I can get higher-quality electronics at cheaper prices
I loved my cheaper Samsung models from my carrier before, so I decided to stick with Samsung and just get an unlocked higher-end model since my previous phones weren't charging after a year of use

This phone has plenty of storage, the screen is a great size, it's much faster than my previous phone, it works with AT&T as advertised, and I'm in love with it, partly because it's purple! I definitely love my Samsungs!For a renewed product, this phone is in EXCELLENT shape

The fingerprint scanner works great
The sound quality is great
There is only a slight smudge of the case on the back of the phone and no other marks

Everything works perfectly!It arrived on time and very quickly despite the global pandemic, which I'm SUPER happy about since my previous phone wasn't wanting to hold the charger in the port anymore so I needed a new phone ASAP
While this one isn't a 5G model, which I might have chosen if they weren't so expensive renewed, I am beyond happy with my purchase
Plus it's purple! I recommend this model of phone, which is MUCH better than my previous phone, AND I recommend the seller as well!

Buying them on Amazon means no re-upping my Sprint contract, which is good because I prefer to minimize my commitments to any contract
Great Phone - The Complete Package: Screen, battery, Sound, Customization, & an audio jack
Purely impressed!An amazing piece of hardware from Samsung which - to me - excels in all things hardware related, and this is no exception
There is not a single element of the hardware (screen, battery, size, ports, camera, hardware specifications, resilience, and so forth) that isn't outstanding on paper or in action
The added customization, openness,and versatility of the Android OS is welcomed compared to Apple's iOS

The added versatility of the unlocked version is nice if a carrier switch or something of that sort is possible, but may inhibit certain carrier exclusive features depending on the carrier (like digital voicemail)
My only minor complaint is of all the Samsung apps, software, and features (bloatware?) that is crammed into the phone and semi-forces its use
A lot it seems like more of sales pitch rather than adding any value
As an aside, this is my first Android phone, after having all iPhones
I decided to switch to the Galaxy S9 and Android OS after not liking the direction Apple was going with its flagship phones

If you are on the fence about what you want in a phone, I highly recommend Samsung brand, but also specifically either this phone, or the Samsung S9+
My mom got this phone after years of using a S4 and her transition was very smooth
Although this phone has a lot of bangs and whistles, I think she has gotten used to using it far faster than we thought she would
She is taking and sending pictures a lot more than she ever has before, and has even figured out how to use some of the other basic functions that she would not have used before
She is very happy with her purchase, and would recommend this product
Samsung has done a wonderful job with developing their product
I personally have the + and I think the only real difference, is screen size
Either way, you will be happy with this!

The Galaxy S9 was a replacement for an older generation Galaxy that could no longer hold all of the apps I use
My smartphone use consists primarily of voice, text, search, and GPS guidance functions and an occasional photograph

Make Sure You Have The Correct Model Number
My three stars has more to do with Amazon's screw up than the phone itself
WHEN YOU GET YOUR PHONE, CHECK THE MODEL NUMBER !!!SHOULD BE SM-G960U1
I ordered the US unlocked Galaxy S9 (model number SM-G960U1), BUT Amazon sent me a Chinese unlocked phone (model number SM-G9600)
It took me over a month to figure out why my wonderful Galaxy S9 was a piece of crap
After much to do, Amazon replaced my Chinese phone with the correct one

I love the Samsung galaxy S9 Plus

Beautiful pixel dense screen that is very rich in color, although I would have preferred if the screen wasn't rounded on the edges as I would sometimes trigger a touch on the sides when I don't want it to
Battery life is more than enough for me, being able to live through my office hours with light use (texting, checking emails, maybe some videos) for 8 hours
Gaming on this phone is really nice compared to my previous phone as it never gets hot just slightly warm when playing heavier titles like PUBG or any other game with a lot of 3d rendering

A gripe I have with this phone, is that the camera in the front isn't as high of a quality as I would like it to be, I would have liked it to be the same quality of the camera on the rear, which is excellent
One last thing about this phone is the just a minor annoyance is the bixby button, its annoying because all it does is summon bixby (voice assistant) something that I find no use for

Does work with Spectrum (AFTER SOFTWARE UPDATE!!!)
I have seen where people say this phone doesn't work with Spectrum (and other carriers) and I ALMOST returned the two phones I bought
When I went to activate this phone with Spectrum the technician said it didn't need the software update first (although the website at Spectrum says to update software first)
When the phone wouldn't activate the technician said it was a locked phone and wouldn't work
Even checked with a supervisor, insisting the phones were locked
I started the return process and went to buy these phone in the Spectrum store
As a last ditch effort while in the store I updated the OS/Android/Software and had them try and activate it again
It worked fine
If your new phone is not working with Spectrum, JUST UPDATE THE OS then try again
What a nightmare
They should put this information in the product description or some how ship them with updated software to begin with
Besides this nightmare the phone is great at a great price

So Far So Good, Shipping Went Well
Note that this review is of how the product arrived and first day thoughts, it's not in-depth of the phone long-term
Contrary to what a few other customers seemed to have experienced in some reviews, my phone came completely brand new and not tampered with at all
I bought this phone unlocked and new in order to avoid the Verizon bloatware I never used but couldn't manage to get rid of
My initial thoughts are: it's fantastic
The picture quality is stunning, especially coming from a Droid Turbo II (which was a nice phone for what it was, but the screen is so lackluster in comparison
The speakers are surprisingly clear and sound great
The slim and tall design feels much better in my hand than I was expecting it to, coming from a smaller phone
I love the shortcuts on this Android version and just how the entire Galaxy line operates in general

I bought this phone because it could be used with CDMA and SIM cards both
I had planned on using Verizon at home and wanted to be able to purchase SIM cards to use in the phone when I travel internationally
But this phone appears to be an AT&T phone that is unlocked so that it can also be used on T-mobile and presumably, other SIM cards
I have wasted a week's time, tried a couple of different SIM cards from a couple of different carriers, purchased a new SIM card, and am just DONE with this
Do not believe the Q&A section where it says the phone can be used with all 4 carriers
It absolutely CANNOT
I will be returning this

Bought from Amazon, activated with Sprint
I just started using this phone so too early for a definitive review
I am mainly going to address some issues brought up by others since there are a lot of problems people are writing about
One of the big issues with these reviews is that people don't usually include who was the actual seller of the product
As most hopefully realize, just because you buy a product on Amazon doesn't mean it was actually sold by Amazon
Many third party sellers sell through Amazon
This is especially a problem for electronics where there are so many variations in model numbers and gray market devices one could end up with an expensive paper weight
I suspect that is the source of many of the issues with this product
Make sure you know the seller
My invoice shows: Sold by: Amazon Services, Inc
Gray market goods typically don't have a warranty
Also see if the item comes with Amazon support
My Galaxy S9 specifically stated 90 day support from Amazon for any issues
I bought the 128 gb version of the S9 to replace a Galaxy S7 Edge
This is the 4th galaxy device I've had so I am familiar with the setup
Once the device arrived I turned it on and enabled Wif Fi to get it up and running as much as possible
I then used the installed Smart Switch software from Samsung to transfer everything from my old phone to the new one
I couldn't get it to work wirelessly but using the cable and included adapter it worked without a hitch
I then attempted to use the sim card from my old phone to get activated on my existing Sprint account
The sim card is in a tray at the top edge of the phone
Use the included tool or paperclip to open the tray
I was unsuccessful in activating through the phone and online
That was also unsuccessful
Likely issue was my old sim card was not compatible
Next day I did just that
The woman who helped me was not familiar with the process of someone bringing in their own phone but with help from the supervisor I got the new card and the phone activated in about 15 minutes
The actual charge: $0!So the answer to the question do these unlocked phones really work is yes
Other things to note: the S9 uses a type C USB cable
It is a different size connector and enables fast charging
If your current phone has one you can simply install it in the new phone or buy a new one
Couple additional items of note: the home button is now virtual instead of physical
Cannot hear unless the speaker is on
A really good phone, neat features
The speaker is not working after about two weeks
-118 dB is just this side of unusable
The phone is fast, with a solid build
But the signal reception is horrible
At my home the signal is always weak, but my Motorola G5 Plus had much better reception
The range for cell service is -50 to -120
Closer to -50 is better, but this S9 is -118 in a weak area, but still -113 in a good area!If you don't need a 3
It's far better as a phone, and motorola really knows what they're doing with convenience
I loved my G5+, but I loved my Samsung S3, S4 and S5 too
But this S9 is pretty poor

It was reset, but locked to AT&T

December 5th, 2021 @ 10:54 PM CDTAfter jumping through hoops with AT&T's terrible customer service representatives and those reps eventually understanding that I don't want to switch service providers and I don't want to be an AT&T customer they finally directed me to the part of their website that allows their customers to request their phone be unlocked
After AT&T verified the phone was paid for, not stolen, and so on they gave me a code to use during set up with my service provider that did allow me to use my preferred service provider
My mom has been happily using her new Galaxy S9 phone for 1 month
So long story short if you don't have time to jump through hoops for a reset but not service unlocked phone then keep looking
But if you do have the time and patience to deal with that then it is a quality product and I highly recommend purchasing it

I should also mention that I am already a proud owner of a Samsung Galaxy S9 so I can say that physically this (Amazon) phone feels and looks the same as mine, I bought this phone on Amazon to give to my mom
It does have a valid IMEI number and I got Samsung to verify that the device is a legitimate Samsung phone
Now for the problems it is NOT factory unlocked as advertised and rather it is locked to AT&T
My concern though is the seller lied about it being factory unlocked so was this phone lost, stolen, has past due balance, some other horrible thing in its past I don't know
But needless to say, if AT&T won't unlock the phone then I'll be returning it to Amazon immediately

Great upgrade as a phone, poor blotchy photo quality albeit brighter low light pics
I bought this phone thinking that it would be better than my current S6 Edge - and just about in every way it is specially low light shots, but disappointed with the picture AI results in general
I normally use my phone as a camera, less so as a computer or streaming device
Sure wide shots look indiscernible, but once you want to see some details the S9+ images become murky at 100% zoom as the Auto settings normally changes to F1
5 (no you cannot force it to use F2
4 in auto mode - which most users use)Fonts looks blotchy upon closer inspection
Yes I understand you can set it to Pro mode so you can do this, but most times I use my phone to take pictures within 3 secs, no time for fiddling with settings
The S6 has a 16M native resolution at 4x3, so setting it to 16x9 reduces resolution to 12M
The 9+ has a 12M native resolution at 4x3, so setting it to 16x9 reduces resolution to 9M
Quite possible this may be causing it, but I read the Pixel has the same resolution but takes better photos because of the AI implementation
I normally shoot at 16x9 size settings so it fills my monitor screen and FB uploads, and this is how I compared the shots
Aside from the uploaded picture, I have also compared outside scenes on both phones - and I do notice slightly murkier pictures with the S9+

In the DLSR world, sometimes you get bad lens so the logical thing is to replace the lens for a sharper one, but not everyone has this luxury with a phone specially if you are at a mobile carrier store with strict use limits
I did a little research and found forums where people complain of the image quality as well, so I don't think I'm in the minority

I have always been a Samsung smartphone loyalist, but that ends now

Samsung makes the best displays on the market, and I love almost everything about this phone
The picture quality is excellent, but these curved edges and rounded display corners have got to go
Regarding the curved edges - they have no functional propose that couldn't be achieved with a flat screen
No matter how you hold the phone you'll get glare at one edges or the other
Images and text message the edge get distorted
On-screen buttons at the edge are problematic at best
The curved edges make it virtually impossible for a case to properly protect the phone if dropped
The rounded display corners are ridiculous
In many apps it really makes no difference, but in some there's just content you can't see
8 is measured as if the corners were not rounded
The fingerprint sensor placement is poor (though common)
If the phone is face up on a table I must pick it up to unlock it (or position my face directly above the screen for other biometrics)
Everything else is great: performance, responsiveness, display quality, battery life - all the things you'd normally expect from a flagship device
But these other bizarre design choices are baffling

I've received numerous error messages and quirks that lead me to believe this phone has been region locked or has an incompatible firmware
Software update: One of the first things I tried to do with this phone was downloading updates for it
When you navigate to Settings > Software Update > Download updates manually | The phone displays registering device and then processing failed
Samsung Pay: When I try to open it says Access to Smasung Pay has been denied
The next time I tried to open it says Samsung Pay is not supported on this device
A SAMSUNG!Region: After experiencing these quirks I went to Settings > About Phone | where i discovered the region is set to United Arab Emirates
Why would that be? The product even said United State Warranty in the description?Bixby:When I swipe left to Bixby Home, scrolling down to the news cards Newsroom youtube Yahoo etc
The language is set to english in phone and bixby settings
Samsung +: after experiencing much slower youtube speeds over mobile data than my previous S7 active, I downloaded Samsung+ to do a speed test

When I navigate to Samsung+ > Diagnostic tools > Connection Speed Test > Mobile > Start speed test | it says connected to AT&T LTE Network, displays a ping reading for a few seconds, then says Test Cancelled
Samsung Smart Switch: Samsung Smart switch will not recognize my device, saying it is incompatible
All of theses quirks lead me to beleive something is seriously defective or incompatible about my version of this phone
I can't download software updates
I am having serious anxiety over this purchase and warn anyone from buying such an expensive item from a third party seller
I put a return/refund request to JD Electronics and have not heard back from them yet
Will update this if they contact me

Gifted It To My Sister In Law
Bad color reproduction, overbearing knox
Can't complain about speed, it performs fine
Color reproduction from camera to screen is quite bad - looks like it's quite over-contrasted, and excessively brightened
Photos look vibrant, sure, but not correct, and a lot of detail can be lost
Sadly a step down from my prior phone in the dark, pictures are quite grainy (and again reproduction is bad), but it might not be bad compared to many other phones
The screen is rather prone to scratches
The curved aspect of the screen is really annoying - the only purpose it seems to serve is to increase the market for cases
All it does is make it easier for accidental touches
Doesn't help edge swipes, either
It does also increase the area of the phone that is extra fragile
Then there is the Knox stuff - that's basically malicious, given that it'll permanently damage the system if it so much as detects that the phone has been customized (rooted)
Not trusting custom firmware while it is active is one thing, but even after restoring it to factory state, if it had ever been flagged, it will stay that way
I've got workarounds for some of these, and others don't impact me enough to change it now, but I'll be looking for a phone without these annoyances if possible next time I upgrade

The 9 on the real S9 + box is completely different and no real Samsung S9 Plus boxes will have the Samsung Pay logo on the top right
Every this in this box is a cheap knock off of the real Samsung equipment
I added a picture of the box, if the 9 on your box looks the same and or you have the Samsung Pay logo on the top right, you have a $200S9 plus clone

Completely broken notifications. Curved glass is a disaster. Excellent display.
I am completely perplexed that this thing has such bad notifications
I use LG, Pixel and Iphone, saw it all, and had reasons to abandon Samsung long time ago
Decided to try S9due it's small size; the only other option was Google Pixel but its display is just too bad
Limited notifications on locked screen:Shows two lines vs full screen + scroll on iphone
Raise to wakeup and show notifications:With iphone/Pixel/Nexus, I would pickup the phone and the accelerometar would wake up the phone, showingnotifications
Notifications while using the phone:Some message comes in, the phone does NOTHING
All this regardless of Notification Sounds settings and Silent mode
Samsung knows that but they failed to get it right
All in all, I am relying on my Pebble to show me notifications
Some 3rd party apps allow coping with most of these problems but they are unreliable, sometimes power hungry or not persistent
First crazy option: Edge screen Notifications
i don't know what
Second crazyoption: Turn On screensaver when screen is off
Fourth crazy option: You can enable vibration when you pickup the phone, if there was some notification
I was thinking working hard getting different 3rd party apps until I fix the notifications to suit my needs
In addition, curved glass easily breaks as the glass is exposed
And not to forget the screen protector - THERE ARE NO GOOD glass screen protectors on the market (yet)
All in all, I am returning this one, and will wait to see what LG G7 will look like
Some notable positive sides:Samsung Internet browser is just awesome
LCD is excellent
Starting camera with double click to Power button
Photos *with flash* in dim conditions are ages ahead of the iphone
Home button is there - just press glass a bit harder
Speakerphone is much louder than Iphone 7
I am reducing this to one star due to so many bugs

My few grievances are the charging port and screen scratch resistance
I highly recommend buying a screen protector
The charging port has become rather dirty, so wired charging is tricky to pull off
But the phone continues to perform well
Screen resolution can be changed between 1480x720 up to 2960x1440
Speaker audio is well enough to play my music when doing whatever in my room
Battery life is still great and lasts me more than a usual day
The storage capacity of 64GB is more than enough for me, I still have 27
RAM of 8GB offers smooth performance, even if I forget to close background apps
The point being, I wouldn't mind buying this phone again, instead of upgrading, if I suddenly lost my current one

Please don't buy
Some advice you'll be needing if you buy this phone.
I like the design and materials, the fact that it fits in my hand, there's no bloatware, the edge to edge display, the titanium protected edges, and the ceramic back
What I despise is the Android OS, 8 and 9, namely the lousy voice to text
It is hands down, the most annoying thing about this phone
For instance, if I say, There are 'two' of them on the floor, it will come up with, There are 'too' of them on the floor, or There are 'to' of them on the floor
That's really annoying, especially to haveto constantly edit every sentence and paragraph so you don't sound like a retard
It also has very serious problems with tense
If I say, I looked back there already, it willcome up with, I look back there already

It does thisconstantly with any word that can be present or past tense and 95% of the time gets it wrong, and the only conclusion I can make is that the hardware came from China, that's exactly how they speak when they speak English, and somehow their most common grammatical mistakes were programmed into the phone
Another issue is that when I say something like, She's there now, it will actually come up with, You there now
She and You are two completely different words which don't even rhyme, yet that keeps happening all the time as well
Also if it's he, they, etc

It also capitalizes business names, like Microsoft, so in essence Google commercialized text messaging and based capitalization on the film industry and business names, as if we out here in the world had nothing else to talk about
It also keeps randomly capitalizing words within sentences, and very often doesn't capitalize the first letter in a sentence
I haven't even mentioned ALL the problems here, but Google did nothing about any of this for Android 9, so even though I updated to the new OS I'm still having the same issues
The voice to text in this phone is just plain garbage software which needs to be completely reprogrammed
The next thing is the camera
I worked with Essential on this and they came out with an update, but I recommend using Open Camera as the default

The problem with the Essential camera app is that you can't change recording quality settings, and in order to prevent the popping sound you get through the speakers you have to set everything to maximum 4k Ultra
You can do this with Open Cam, but not with Essential's app, plus Open Camera has a bunch of other features you'd find on DSLR's

Another issue I worked with Essential on was the sound issue, which as I stated above will be alleviated when recording a video once you set the maximum recording quality, but if you play certain videos online, or wave files, there can be a lot of clicking sounds going on
Not all, but some
It either has something to do with the hardware, or the audio codec responsible for decoding the sound
I'm sure they'll figure it out soon enough, but the problem still exists even with Android 9
I just tested it
And then another issue, which Google is once again responsible for since this has to do with Google Maps
With iPhone and say, a 2011 Hyundai with Bluetooth, it works seamlessly
You connect to your radio and no matter what input you select the Google Maps directions will play over your speakers while you can still hear the music
It just dims the music down a bit
But with Android, it's completely retarded

You have to select Phone on the radio, and then you can hear the directions but no music at all, and even if you load your phone up with tracks, the steering wheel controls do not control any player within the phone, so if you want to change tracks or do anything you have to look at the phone to do it, which is something I refuse to do while driving

The other retarded thing is that if I have the radio playing, either music or CD or whatever else, the Google Maps will only cut in the way it works with iPhone IF you're on the phone talking to someone
That is really annoying because it interferes with your conversation and works EXACTLY OPPOSITE of the way it's supposed to work
I don't know what these people at Google are doing, but they sure are selling some pretty messed up products
Seems they're more interested in spying on everyone than anything else, which is why I completely disabled Chrome in my phone
So that's about it for now
It's a nice phone, don't get me wrong
But until Google hires a non-Chinese grammatical expert and a programming team to fix voice to text, and Essential fixes the other issues, it can be really annoying to use

I'm really surprised that Google was able to get away with coming out on the market with such a buggy piece of garbage software like that, and I know it's the software and not the phone because my new Stylo 3 was just as bad
Highly recommend you READ BACK before sending emails or texts, because some of the mistakes are not cool
Once I said, I need to get some gas, and the phone came up with, I need to get some ass
Funny now, but what if I didn't notice and that text was going to someone who wouldn't appreciate it so much, like your supervisor or mother
I'm surprised Google hasn't been sued for these kinds of mistakes
Update - if you've been having the same problems with voice to text that I've been having, I found the answer
It's not perfect, but it's certainly better than Google's gboard
It still makes tense mistakes and doesn't choose the correct version of certain words, but the Swiftkey autocorrect can help thatsometimes

I bought the Essential Phone with the intention of possibly using it as a backup for my Samsung S9+ and as a replacement for my Son's Samsung S6/7 Edge
He was adamant about NOT wanting an Unknown Iphone Look-a-like, or a Google Pixel Phone that probably sucks

Neither of us wanted to give up all the great qualities of our Current Samsung phones for anything, but we gave the Essential Phone a go; And we couldn't be happier!The Look, Feel and Ease of use of this phone is unmatched it almost every way
The Essential phone somewhat resembles an IPhone at first glance, but once you pick it up there's no denying this is NOTHING like ANYTHING that's on the market
Its body is so soft and slick that it does not like to be set on anything that's not a FLAT surface, and so far that is the ONLY complaint that I have about this phone
It loaded our DJI Mavic Pro App with NO GLITCHES or issues, and this is a HUGE app
The operation is fast, reliable and beautifully designed
Totally user friendly, and just unbelievable quality video and pictures
Do spend the extra money to get the 360 camera, as its an awesome little addition to this total phone package!
Awesome value!

With most of my smartphone experience being on Android, I was letdown to say the least with all the typical inconsistencies and experiences I had over the years

Being an avid Android enthusiast and devouring any bit of Essential phone news I can find since it was initially announced, it was hard to resist at least trying it before committing to the iPhone further with the recent iPhone 8 Plus
Going into the Sprint store and seeing the Essential phone their and having some quick hands-on time with it, I was immediately impressed with the hand-in feel
It was definitely an Ahhh moment when I opened to box, I probably put too much emphasis on presentation but I am so glad I'm not the only one that obsesses over small details
Build quality, presentation aside, focusing on the phone and how it is to use
For me for the most part, it is a joy to use

Those who have complained about camera quality and camera speed, I will say first off that I am not a heavy camera user on a smartphone, only taking pictures on occasion so the best camera isn't a high requirement for me, if it is to you, you may want to look at the LG V30 or the S8/S8+, Pixel or iPhone

Overall usability to me is far more important and being able to quickly transition between apps/screens is a joy to experience on a device with no bloatware to speak of, just clean Android as Andy Rubin intended with this device
If build quality, up to date Android releases, a fast, fluid UI experience are things you value then you can't go wrong with the Essential

The Essential Phone makes me… happy!?!Yeah, I know weird
I have the awesome opportunity to trial tons of new handsets from utilitarian to flagship and yet somehow this Essential Phone with LESS tricks and gimmicks is my current favorite over all
I don’t know any other way to put it
Running a finger across the screen feels SO nice
What else? A clean android experience
It’s fast – blazing fast
Sliding up from the bottom brings up the app tray snappy and fast too
I know, nowadays people love all the additional options, but that isn’t what this device is really about

Other options are still available in the settings menu for example the ability to turn on/off NFC, though anyone that uses NFC would probably argue they keep this on most of the time and not need to shut it off in a hurry
Which by the way, if all that customization is important you can always go with a ‘launcher’ from the Play store rather than one that’s forced upon you by a device manufacturer
I do agree at times it’s nice to have some of the manufacturer specific options and things we’re used to seeing (like Touchwiz/Saumsung Experience)
I just hadn’t realized what I gave up in Android responsiveness in order to have the manufacturer specific Android mods
I may have to test it out with a launcher at some stage just to see if it functions as fast as it feels now
The default ringtone is nice and not obnoxious and I like the new unobtrusive text tone too
It’s all google messaging with the latest version as well as google keyboard and ability to text with GIF’s etc
My favorite feature so far? Home Screen Rotation!I haven’t seen a handset where the home screen turns! Almost all handsets don’t rotate the actual home screen, only the apps
The screen and colors are beautiful too
By the way, for those reading… I think the S8 is an amazing device and I’m not knocking it in any way

A great option for size, robustness, and lack of unnecessary extras
I've used this for about 24 hours now and want to get a review up quickly prior to the release date for those who are considering this
Here are the highlights
For reference, my current phone is a Samsung S7 edge on Verizon
Popped the sim card out of the S7e, popped it into the Essential, when through some setup steps on the phone, connected my Google accounts, and it was operational
It let me select which of my apps I wanted to re-download and installed them (could take all with one click, but I de-selected some that I don't use first)
I used the Content Transfer app from Verizon (free in the Google Play store) to transfer message history, photos, videos, etc
I was up and running with everything I use without missing a beat
The only thing I didn't see an easy way to replicate was the icons and widgets I've selected for my desktop(s), so that's a bit of work to reposition everything the way I like it
It's one of their key selling points (titanium case vs aluminum in other phones), and they have a section on drop tests and not needing a case on their website
While it's not my goal to test this point excessively, I already dropped it accidentally from about 4' onto a hard surface and it was unscratched
Assuming this holds up, and that it in fact doesn't need a case, this is a big win
It's funny how we look at phones in the store naked, admiring their size and design and weight, but then have to protect them in a bulky case
I'm looking forward to using this au naturel
Water resistance: downsideThe Essential makes no claim about water resistance so I assume it would drown
That's a downside vs
I suppose the equalizer would be a waterproof case but that kills the prior point

They have the same screen real estate but the essential cleverly gets rid of the entire top section (where the Samsung logo and camera are) making it more than 1/2 shorter, which is a nice gain at no cost
The Essential cleverly embeds the camera into the screen itself with no real downside since that's where the icon bar sits anyway, so the camera is basically taking up the space of one top icon
When you then add to that the lack of a case (see above), I'd estimate that it's about 20% smaller in overall area and 30% smaller in total volume
That's about the difference for it to be comfortable vs
The screen quality and resolution are very good and seems equal to the S7
Benefit of Essential is that the edge isn't curved - it gets the same amount of screen in the same width and keeps it flat which I prefer
At their respective brightest settings, the S7 is brighter though, which maybe helpful in daylight outdoor situations

GPS (with Endomondo for running)Accurate, with just a little wobble, same as S7Headphones - no jackI'd prefer a regular headphone jack, but the supplied adapter worked fine and my regular headphones worked with it without issue
Fingerprint sensor - well done for 1-handed operationThe sensor is positioned on the back, which turns out to be a very comfortable spot for 1-handed operation
This again speaks to it not needing a case - if a case were used you couldn't access the reader
The S7 is a little more awkward for 1-hand with the reader at the bottom of the front

Phone itselfSound quality is fine (on par with S7) for both hearing and speakingDock for charging - coming soon (I hope!)The biggest missing item out of the gate for me, that I love with my S7, is the wireless charging dock
I have one at my desk and one by my bed for the S7, I use the Seneo which is great
I just drop the phone onto the dock and it sits at a perfect 60 degree angle as an alarm clock while charging
The Essential website indicates that this is coming, although from the photos the dock appears to be just lying flat
I assume a 3rd party will come out with something to address this
Otherwise it's as good or better than alternatives in other respects, and I'm very happy with it
Edit #1 - 9/6/17As of now, visual voicemail is not set up for this device with Verizon
Agent said that it typical of new devices so it shouldn't be a lasting issue
Regular voicemail (dial in) works fine

I purchased this phone directly from Best Buy because I could pick it up same day with a price match at $449
00 from Amazon
First off, the phone itself is an absolute beast
-It is stock running near stock Android, with the only non-stock software being the Essential camera app, and it is smooth
-Battery life gets me through most of the day, but it really depends on how much the phone itself spends looking for signal strength

If you want about 24 hours of battery life, then turn on battery saver; otherwise, the phone has quick-charge, the 27 watt-hour charging brick with USB-C cable, and will charge your phone from 0-100% in about 1hr and 15 minutes

I can attest to that since I have done it now three times and timed it myself to see if the estimated time to 100% was accurately reflected in the battery settings and I am happy to report that it is :)
-The body and screen are very durable, but like any phone with Gorilla Glass 5, you will get the wear and tear of normal micro-scratches
For the haters out there, remember this, the iPhone X has the same glass which gets the same normal wear and tear with micro-scratches
-The OS plays nicely, and you can even opt-in for the Android beta programs to get the latest and greatest OS quickly from Essential before an official release
Essential provides a way back to your previous OS version as well
The other item that you need to consider is the support
Essential provides great customer service to support the PH-1
Remember that, you are getting monthly security patches, and a new report has even stated that Essential and Google are the BEST at provided security patches, updates, and customer service
Something to think about

Of the should haves, the phone only manages 4
First off, it offers a unique modular system for adding modular functionality
On top of the above, you should know that this phone incorporates USB-C, the new USB standard that, unfortunately, isn't directly compatible with your old USB cables

On the whole, I find a lot to like about this phone, and some things--like the elegant high quality build and no bezel screen--to love

But even with a just-good-enough camera and with the design choice headaches, in the past month I've come to love certain things about this phone: The form factor; the feel in my hand;the glassy smooth performance; the super fast booting; the lovely edge-to-edge display; and the (surprisingly) consistently excellent battery life

I keep hoping a firmware update will fix things, and that's why I waited to write this update until the just released update of today, but it didn't fix anything in this regard and so
I love this phone and will be a loyal customer of Essential for a long time to come...

Fantastic phone
Premium feel with a (new) mid-tier price that is very competitive
The Essential Phone has a rather impressive screen and overall design that comes up just short as a flagship phone, but is highly competitive as a mid-tier device
I've been using the Essential Phone on and off as my daily driver for over a month now
When I first received the device, I had mixed impressions about it
For starters, it was initially priced around $700, on par with a Galaxy S8
The build and feel of the device are just
I've previously been a user of the Nexus 5X, and I felt burned by it time and time again with camera issues and random freezes
When I first got the Essential Phone, I was having some flashbacks to the Nexus, especially when I was using the camera
Over the past month+, though, there have been several updates that have improved the camera performance and consistency, and have cleaned-up random freezes
In contrast to the Nexus 5X, and to the Pixel - the Essential Phone feels different
The titanium body and ceramic back feels new and cool and
Kinda like how it felt to be the first person to have an iPhone 4
The phone is light enough to handle, but has the right amount of heft to still come across as substantial
You really have to hold it to truly appreciate the difference

As far as the hardware is concerned, the Essential Phone has a mostly bezeless screen, a USB C port (no headphone jack!), a power button and volume rocker, dual camera in the back that sits flush, and fingerprint reader in the back
The star of the show is the screen, which only has a little circular cut-out at the top for the forward facing camera
The screen is unfortunately LCD and not OLED
It can't generate the totally black blacks of this year's OLED phones or an LG C7 television
but make no mistake, this screen is still a quality performer

The blacks are as good as it's going to get on an LCD display, and I could only truly appreciate the contrast differences when I put it next to a Galaxy S8 (I haven't used an iPhone X yet), and it looks better than an iPhone 7 screen

The camera notch at the top didn't bother me 99% of the time, the only time it became annoying was on certain web pages with unique formatting where the whole page fit on one screen and it just cut off a word/link from a menu that I had a hard time selecting
The internals are solid with 128GB of storage and the current flavor of high-end Snapdragon processor with 4GB of RAM
The Essential Phone holds it's own when it comes to daily performance
I didn't really have any complaints after a couple of system updates
As far as I can tell, the Essential Phone pretty much gives you stock Android 7
The camera software is a little different than stock Android, but I couldn't really find any other differences
Hopefully this leads to timely updates and an edge on Samsung, HTC, OnePlus and LG phones
The camera's performance has become better with a couple updates, but it's still not as great as some of the competition
I like the coloring and saturation in pictures of the S8 better, and I feel like the S8 takes more consistent photos
As far as the fingerprint reader goes, it works well, is pretty quick, and I think it's location on the middle back is ideal
The Essential Phone also has a unique magnetic port of sorts on the top of the phone to quickly attach accessories without the need for Bluetooth data transfer or stand-alone power
I didn't get a chance to try out the 1 accessory they currently have, a 360 camera, but I'm intrigued to see what Essential Phone may offer next
The magnetic port is a cool concept, though
So where are the shortcomings for the Essential Phone?Well, call me a dinosaur, but I'd still like a dedicated headphone jack
The Essential Phone doesn't have a microSD card slot, but with 128GB of space, it doesn't bother me much
space isn't the real issue here, I just wish I could pop the card out and transfer a couple hundred photos and movies easily via card, instead of going through OneDrive or GoogleDrive
The bigger omission at this point is the lack of waterproofing that the main competition can boast
When the Essential Phone was $700, this was a huge problem and these shortcomings would have made me drop it to 3-stars
But with the price drop, this is maybe the best phone you can get in the mid-tier price range and I can overlook some of the limitations
So with the price drop to the mid-tier range, if you are looking at Android, this is a better choice than a Pixel 1 or older Galaxy and a much better value than an iPhone 7

Since the Nexus program was discontinued, I felt my options were quite limited, especially as a Sprint customer

I am very particular about what I look for in a phone:Unlockable bootloaderAbility to root/install custom ROMs/recoveryStock/near stock AndroidFast updatesCommunity supportThe first time I held the phone in my hand I was blown away by the build quality
Even the box it comes in feels premium
I've never felt such a solid phone, even compared to other flagship devices and/or certain fruity phones
I do use a rugged case to protect the phone from any potential damage, but only because I ride a motorcycle
Ideally I would love to show off its beauty and not use a case but it's a risk I'm not willing to take

Weak cell signal can be a problem
The Essential Phone has premium build quality, a great display, takes pretty good pictures, runs pure Android without a scrap of bloat and receives regular updates (at least so far)
Like a Nexus or Pixel phone it is also capable of running on GSM or CDMA networks
It's also the perfect size if you don't want a huge phone
It still feels like a large screen phone but can be handled comfortably in one hand or two
This should be a fantastic phone but there's a serious design flaw that Essential refuses to officially acknowledge--the porcelain used in the phone's body seems to interfere with cell reception
When measuring your phone signal a lower number is better
According to the testing apps I have been using-110dBm is the cut-off where you start to experience service problems on a GSM network and -90dBm is the cut-off on a CDMA network
On an OP5, Nexus 6P or Pixel XL the T-Mobile network signal measures in the -85dBm to -90dBm range anywhere in my apartment
Using the same SIM in the Essential Phone results in a signal in the -100dBm to -105dBm range
I initially thought it was a T-Mobile network issue with this phone
Since Sprint is the one network that officially supports the Essential Phone I figured switching to Sprint would improve the service

I bought a Boost Mobile SIM card (they use the Sprint network), ported my phone number over, factory reset the phone, set up everything to work properly with my new network--and my service was actually worse
I was getting a very steady -92dBm signal which would have been great on T-Mobile but is terrible on Sprint
The call quality was so poor that when I called Boost Mobile the service people had difficulty understanding me
I eventually had to use Google Voice on my Nexus 6P to talk to Boost Mobile
Technical support tried boosting the signal and some other things but in the end, I had to cancel the service, lost my phone number and ended up going back to T-Mobile
My signal on T-Mobile is weaker than it should be but still good enough that I can use the phone
Others ended up returning theirs because the weaker phone reception made the Essential too unreliable to use daily
But many people say that their cell service is fine

T-Mobile users have reported the most problems but the same issue has been encountered by people using AT&T, Verizon and Sprint so whether your service will be good or not seems to be impossible to predict
The video on the Essential website that shows their phone bouncing around on pavement and not getting damaged is a bit misleading
They claim the titanium and ceramic body of the Essential phone is more durable than the aluminum other phones use and that's true as far as it goes
What they don't tell you is that the screen is very susceptible to cracking if the phone is dropped face down from a height of even a few feet
I don't know that the Essential is actually more fragile than any other phone with an edge to edge display but if you are prone to dropping your phone this probably isn't a good choice
People have reported screen damage from drops while using both a case and screen protector so how much protection either actually provides is debatable
If you love the design of the Essential Phone and plan on using it naked the Black Moon version is not the one to buy
The body of this phone attracts fingerprints and smudges more quickly than anything I have ever seen
After an hour of use, I couldn't wait to get my phone into a case
The body of the Halo Gray version reportedly does not suffer from the same fingerprint issue
The Essential Phone probably represents the best combination of style, build quality and software experience that you can currently get in the $500 price range
But if you do buy this phone make sure to use a retailer that offers no hassle returns because it's possible you will experience cell service issues

I tried a different outlet
I tried rebooting
I tried rebooting again
This was all occurring with the factory supplied charger and cable
After several attempts to get it to work, I purchased a standard USB to USB-C cable and tried my Motorola charger on the phone
Just for grins and giggles, I attempted another charge with the factory supplied hardware the next night when the phone was almost flat
It worked fine
Charging the phone from single digits to close to 100% in less than an hour
This has happened twice now - the last time was earlier this week (mid August 2018)
Same behavior and same fix
Pulled out the old Motorola charger, got the standard USB to USB-C cable from the truck and it started charging
Went back to the Essential charger the next night

I've had this phone for about a month now - overall I've been impressed with it given the price
I needed a phone in a hurry when my 2 year old Moto Droid up and bricked itself one morning
I was eyeing the Pixel 2, but I didn't like the price - so I went with this instead
The specs (memory and processor) make this a zippy phone - as expected
No additional OME software junk - stock Android for the win!Screen - In comparison to some Flagship phones, this screen isn't as impressive
The call quality isn't as good as some other phones and it is due mainly to the location of the speaker and mic IMO
Since the front is all screen, the speaker is pointing up making it so you'll end up holding the phone lower so the top of it is near the center of your ear
Not great - but a design trade-off they made
Same thing with the mic, since it is at the bottom edge pointing downward, the phone it doesn't pick up as well as other designs
I know a lot of other manufacturers are doing this too - sacrificing phone audio quality for clean fronts and larger screen size
Since I buy cell phones in part to be, you know, a phone - I'm not a fan of this design choice
If you are just reading specs and possible going into stores to look at phones, you won't notice this as even in stores you can't use the speaker/mic to test out the phone call quality
Both Apple and Google have better designs in this area IMO
So if this is a big issue for you, this could be a deal breaker
Camera - It's good
If I want a better camera I'll buy the 180 clip on attachment or I'll use a standard hand held camera
For taking pics of the kids and whatnot - it works well
Finger Print Scanner - Works well
Took a bit of getting used to the placement (center of the back) - but now I've got the muscle memory down it is fine
Convenient for unlocking the phone quickly and many apps use it for password unlock if you set it up (very convenient)
Customer service - Timely and responsive

I'd heard some pretty questionable things about this phone, but I have to say I'm impressed with it
It's a marriage of form and function like you usually only see with iOS devices -- I got this for my husband, who had an ancient Samsung phone, and it's prettier than my iPhone 7 by a long shot
I'm actually a little bit jealous
So here's the takeaway so far:* The form factor:The screen is gorgeous
Really nice display, true colors
But more than that, the phone looks stunning (he gets questions about it all the time) and it feels so good to hold
It feels like something that should cost the kind of money that phones cost these days
It does have a little bit of weight to it, but the weight, I think is part of what makes it so nice to hold
The display taking up the whole face of the phone really does look nice
I can't say how it works because my husband doesn't take many pictures, but what I've seen so far has been pretty good
The camera did seem to perform pretty well, I noticed, with the pictures that saw him take while we were out at a convention earlier today
There was no lag time between pressing the button to take the picture and the picture actually being taken
I didn't get a phone with the detachable 360 degree camera, so I can't tell you how well that performs
This is Android the way it's supposed to look, and my god, it's like a totally different operating system
Everything is easy to get at, all the settings
Everything is customizable
Everything responds quickly to the touch

I understand the appeal of Android now, and if you're someone who was on the verge of moving it iOS because you don't like the crap Android can put you through, give this phone a look, because it's a very different experience
I know, it's horrible
Except it isn't, really
I've had an iPhone 7 for a while now, and even without wireless headphones, I haven't missed it
As with the iPhone, it comes with an adapter to let you plug standard headphones into the phone
The adapter is pretty sleek, and doesn't feel much different than just having the cord there
But the point here being that micro USB-based chargers will need an adapter unless they're USB C
The battery life is apparently stellar
Which is good, because he's always forgetting to charge his phone
It also charges really fast
All in all, I think this phone performs up there with my iPhone 7, as good if not better
I think if I was going to get an Android phone, based on my husband's experience with this one, this is the phone I would want
Software a work in progress, but the hand-feel is better than Iphone X

I've been a Samsung Galaxy user as well as an iOS user for sometime (work and personal phones) and was excited at the opportunity to test this phone
I hate bloatware so felt the essentialness of this phone would be a nice change from the built in apps that typically are baked into most Android builds

BOTTOM LINE UP FRONT:- Huge screen- Missing key features like waterproofing, wireless charging, headphone jack, expandable storage (seriously!)- Good battery life- Promise of accessories like a 360 degree cameraHARDWARE:-The PH-1 sports a 5
7 screen which rivals that Pixel XL, yet somehow feels like a bigger screen

-A titanium frame claims to be stronger than most other materials in other phones, which theoretically should resist the bending issue that most big phones experience when they go into your back pocket
I felt the case felt similar to the new iPhone X feel, without the curved edges of the X
The 128GB is considerable, but one of the usual advantages of Android over iOS is that there is an expansion slot to leverage
Not so in the essential unfortunately
I've seen reports of people complaining about the smaller battery
I found that it's battery easily lasted a full day of normal business use with no issue
For those heavy users that require a recharge throughout the day, it took about an hour to get the battery topped back up into the 90% range
Given the choice, I think ultimately I would stick with my Note 8

Sprint user: Defective, Poor overall experience, and a massive headache.
I spent no fewer than four hours and took two trips to the Sprint store to find an appropriate SIM card
I now have 7 different Sprint SIM Cards from 4 different packages for my effort
Apparently this phone takes a SIMOLW416Q SIM card which took quite a few (understatement) attempts to activate
Sprint managed to reset the phone in the database but it still shows up as the wrong color when I look at my account
After that we went through a series of troubleshooting steps that work with other phones to make them activate to no avail
I'm coming from an iPhone 6s+, and before you give me an 'unhelpful' for that, just know this is my 5th Android device including tablets

The reasons I'm returning mine for two, one: listening to music through the supplied headphone adapter sounds like a blown amp or speaker when playing any kind of music (several sets of headphones, work fine with other devices)
Reason 2, this thing gets zero service in most buildings I go into

On three occasions I've seen it get full signal, zero signal, full, zero, then reboot and completely go crazy (see attached picture) and I have to force reset it (volume up + power for 15 seconds until it flashes and shows the essential logo)
I mentioned Tidal MQA support earlier, it's supposed to be a very high-quality way to listen to music on the go
So that ends my 6-day long adventure with my Essential Phone

So I really wanted to like the Essential phone - however after using returned two of these phones
The screen is beautiful (flat the way I like it) and the OS free of bloatware is nippy
Camera is just ok and auto focus slow

The deal breaker on this phone is cell reception for TMobile (not sure if people on other carriers noted this as well) - cell reception is poorer than other older phones on Tmobile and actually drops from time to time - I got the error SIM Not Found multitudes of times - even after doing various resets on wireless settings as well as a fully factory reset
I thought that the issue may be with my set but the other phone in our family also had call drops
In fact once I did further research the Essential phone seems to have documented issues with TMobile reception (Reddit etc)

My other big issue with Essential was the customer service - they initially were very responsive and even called me back after I left a voicemail on the weekend - but that was that they were interested in logging the 'ticket' and 'follow up' but the solutions offered seemed to be web queries etc and without a genuine interest in alleviating the customers issues or customer satisfaction
They did not even mention or acknowledge the issues with TMobile reception

Cheap phone for a 10 year old
I saw a few negative reviews on this and thought I'd share my experience on this
I wasn't planning to activate the phone service but rather use it exclusively as a WiFi device
Got it on sale for $20 (regular price is $30) and you can't really beat that price
It is a basic smart phone
Decent screen size and camera and decent storage space
For $20, I didn't expect this to have great camera, great speed, big sharp screen or blazing speed that you can play games on
Battery doesn't last 2 days but it's sufficient to last a day under normal usage
The phone is sufficient for a 10 year old who just watches YouTube and text with her friends
I installed Talkatone and it can even be used as an IP phone when she has WiFi
In summary, I didn't have high expectations on camera, screen size, speed
but it definitely is sufficient for a 10 years old

I purchased my TracFone Alcatel 502DL TCL LX for FREE from TracFone last September as a B/UP to my Samsung J3 Luna Pro
I was able to get a generic-boxed RE-CONDITIONED phone for the price of a $15 TALK/TIME card which I needed anyway to continue my TRACFONE SERVICE
it did NOT look re-conditioned but like a new product packaged in a plain white box but with all new accessories
I did purchase a Katin 9H screen protector 2-pak from Amazon with gold/black case for about twelve bucks and they are also spectacular! The battery cover is sealed and batt is not replaceable
By the time the batt loses its useful life I'll be purchasing another TracFone Alcatel upgrade anyway
Before I rave about the phone further
there is one minor criticism I have about the phone
The SIM/MICRO SD card holder on the side of the phone

Original review: The Galaxy A50 is the first phone I've ever bought unlocked
Its battery is the best thing about it, and it's actually why I bought the phone
I'm on AT&T's network and there's been absolutely no reception issues in Texas
The speaker volume is very good and the phone even came pre-installed with a screen protector, which is awesome
This may be a hot take, especially considering others' reviews of it, but the in-screen fingerprint reader is not half bad
The camera's the worst part about the phone, but I feel the default Samsung Camera app does it even more injustice
All that aside though, the camera still offers interesting and fun shots to take
Another minor inconvenience is that the phone lacks Smart Capture entirely, for whatever reason
One last thing is that I notice my touches stick when I type too fast, resulting in accidental swipe text input
Overall though? This is a really good phone
Great phone for an old man.....
Last year we needed new phones
They had an awesome battery but were glitchy from the beginning(not enough time or room to list the details)
I saw an article on the A50 on some website and was intrigued
Even though I could not find a US specific A50 for sale, after some digging I found the SM-A505G model was supposed to be US compatible
It's the Latin America version if I remember right
We took a chance and ordered one A50 and one A30
hoping they would work on AT&T in the midwest
Both phones take NANO sims(not micro) so we had to get different cards before we could try them
Calling worked just fine first try
Texting worked first try
We don't use a huge amount of data, but speeds seem fine
We sent a couple of pics back and forth just to test
We entered the settings
and it worked!!We've only had them about a week, but so far so good
The only Con so far
Some other people mentioned an issue with the fingerprint reader on the A50
At first it worked great
first try, every time
But a day or two later I went to unlock and it did not recognize my fingerprint
After several tries it finally worked
I have deleted fingerprints and redone them and tried several different fingers
It just doesn't work consistently
I hate to say it, but even the BLU phone had a better fingerprint reader
Usually I just give up and enter the pattern
it's faster
Even with this one con I can live with it
Samsung firmware quality
good size for my old eyes(not too big or too small)
We'll probably keep these phones for a long time unless some unforeseen issues pop up
AT&T Tech Support cannot get data to work on their network with the A50
We were very excited to get this phone for the value/functionality
Love my new phone
A must but for MetroPCS users or ones done financing phones
Highly recommend
This phone is a monster
The processor is one of the better Exynos sets and much higher than the A20 with a much better GPU
The screen/display is amazing
Basically this phone is at least on par with a Galaxy S9 and close to the 10
Battery life for me has been weird but I am a very heavy user who is constantly browsing and reading watching Netflix and YouTube

I don't use cell cameras much as I'm in the stone age of social media (hate snap chat and FB) but took a couple photos and they were the best cell phone pictures I have ever taken (in terms of quality)
The bad? Things that don't affect me much
I have not tried face recognition
Overall this phone is a must for MetroPCS users that are interested in the A20 or someone who wants a powerhouse phone without shelling out more than $500
Samsung still has the bloat ware
I paid $238 for mine
Remember to make sure the model purchased will support USA LTE If you are here in the states (some A50 do not
As someone who has had 3 different Notes, the original Galaxy 1 and the 6, this phone is just great
Much better than expected!  I'm very happy with this phone.
I am very impressed by the A50
Coming from a Galaxy S5, the A50 is a big improvement and I had cautious high hopes about size, features and performance
I was not let down
Received model SM-A505G/DS in a sealed Samsung box with a US compatible charger (EP-TA200 15 watt Adaptive Fast Charger) and a rather short 31
Many countries use that same design, but run on 240V
Philippians is one that comes to mind
The A505G/DS model is basically the South American variant of the A50
Setup is easy,fully charge the phone, insert a SIM and the included SD card, then power on, choose your language and wait a few minutes

I transferred the apps, data, settings, contacts, etc from the old phone (Galaxy S5) to the new A50 using the Samsung Smart Switch app (had to download and install on the old phone from the app store)
Then in about 15 minutes the data was wirelessly transferred and apps installed on the A50
Saved me lots of time
The Finger Print reader works very fast
Other reviews claim it is useless, slow etc
I got unlock response times less than 1 second with two fingers prints registered
Adding a third slowed it down to about 1 full second
So I suspect registering 5 fingers will slow it down more
Also note that the phone comes with a tempered glass screen protector already installed, so don't put a another one on top of it or that could mess up touch response and fingerprint reading
Both hand air gestures and near field are not supported with model A505G/DS
I never used these features on my old S5, so I don't miss them on the A50
More about NFC and Samsung Pay later
Bloatware is practically non-existent
There are only a few Google and Samsung apps that can not be uninstalled, but can be disabled
The major offender is Bixby
I know of no one that wants or uses Bixby
There is nothing like all the junk you get with a branded phone
IE games, sports apps, shopping apps, etc that take up lots of memory and just can not be deleted unless you ROOT your phone
The initial 100% charge lasted about 4 hours of WI-Fi , LTE and constant changes to settings, screen savers, install/uninstall, downloads, etc until it was down to about 40%
I finally let it run down to 25% and put it on to charge
An hour later it was back to 100%, and that charge lasted the whole next day of constant use, testing every feature, etc
Every time the battery is recharged, it lasts noticeably longer, and this is typical of a new LION battery
I was very worried that the 4G/LTE bands would not match Cricket Wireless (Cricket is owned by ATT )
The seller listed the bands the phone supports in the Q&A section above, and Cricket Wireless uses LTE Bands B2 (1900 PCS), B4 (1700/2100 AWS 1), B17 (700 bc), and B30 (2300 WCS)
Bands B2, B4, and B17 are supported by the A50 so 4G is working for me even though I am on the fringe of a LTE area getting only 1 or 2 bars tops while having connection on 3 of the 4 Cricket bands
Speed test showed consistent 5 to 6 Mbps download speeds even with such a weak signal
When it was raining hard, the phone was getting H+ (3G)
Note that these bands only apply to the A505G/DS model
The other popular foreign model is A505F/DS and it supports entirely different set of LTE bands
So if you are on a ATT based GSM system, you need the A505G/DS model
The back of this A50 is the iridescent version, about as rigid as the S5 plastic back, and collects fingerprint smudges like you will not believe
But it looks really cool
I'm using a Wallet Case, so the back does not matter to me
The 4GB of ROM are enough for my use, as even with multiple apps running at once, no more than 2
After deleting the installed apps I didn't want, and transferred and/or downloaded more apps, the internal memory shows 39GB free
And that includes what the OS uses
Plenty of room for more apps
All the data, photos, video, etc are on the SD card
A few hours after setting up the phone, an update was downloaded that took about 15-20 minutes to install
Says it improves finger print reader performance, and makes apps and the OS more stable, as well as other things
So far the phone performs flawlessly
The CPU in this phone is very fast
31 Ghz, and 4 up to 1
74 Ghz as measured by the GPU-Z app
Graphics are fast too, and the screen looks great
Haven't tested the camera yet, but so far the few pics I took look very good
When I get home in a few days I'll see how good the pics look on a 27 4K monitor
The audio app works great, has an equalizer and other other features
The included headphones are the hard plastic style, not foam buds
So unless you want to press each piece into your ears while listening to music, they are pretty much only good for phone conversations
The Bluetooth 5
0 is awesome
I only have 4
1 headsets, but the distance 5
0 gives is amazing
Left the phone in the family room, and walked outside
That put 1 interior wall, and one outside wall between me and the phone
I was able to walk about 50 feet from the house before the music broke up
I am able to walk all over 2,500 sq ft ranch with the phone in the middle of the house and not even one hickup in the playback
Also transferred a few files from the laptop (BT 4
Worked well
Was an easy way to copy some stuff to the A50
Fast charging works, well, fast
About 1 hour from about 30% to 100%
The charging tester showed that even though the A50 said 100% charged, but it was not
The charger continued to output slowly diminishing amperage at 9
0 volts for about another 15-20 minutes until the tester showed that the A50 was no longer drawing any power from the charger
So I suggest leaving the A50 on the charger about 15 minutes past the Notification that it is 100% charged to actually get a full charge
Hot spot worked with my laptop in the same room
But with the poor 4G signal I was getting performance was barely OK
Video would not play
I suspect this would improve with a descent 4G signal
Phone calls using only WIFI work great
Sending pictures and texts via WIFI worked good too
A few hours later I logged into my Cricket Wireless account and it was showing the EMEI number from the A50
All and all, the phone is doing what I want and doing it better than expected, and with no glitches, freezing, heating up or slowing down
I'm very happy
In an area that has good 4G, (3,4 out of 5 bars) video phone calls work great
No glitches, no stutter, no voice issues
I have traveled all over town with this phone doing a video chat to Hong Kong perfectly
I gave up trying to get Samsung Pay and Google Pay to work atcheckout, even though the phone has the sensors (NFC) needed for checkout
I was unable to identify the specific sub APL routine that connects the NFC sensor in the phone to the applications that get installed
That seems to be the the problem
Phone has the NFC sensor, but not a driver to connect to apps that need NFC support for checkout
Anyone know where I can download the NFC driver, please let me know
I have manually rebooted the phone about 6 times after big installs and big uninstalls
The phone is working great
I'm keeping my fingers crossed
So it is working well on the Cricket system
If you have an Att account, I believe the cap is 10Gb/s download
You will have to test yourself
Upload tests are not working
But I can upload huge pics with no problems
Multiple huge pics attached to a single text message go in a matter of moments
Emails with 6 or 8 big picture attachments are sent in less than 20 seconds
So the LTE is working well

-La cámara es decente, y el sensor de gran apertura para mi es lo mas llamativo se presta para fotos más interesantes

I upgraded my ancient Samsung Galaxy S3 to this and it was a major improvement
The cameras a great but not top of the line of course
There were a few updates for the phone when I turned it on and one of those was for the fingerprint reader
Excellent Midrange Phone, with unexpected extras
The phone was delivered on time and in good condition
There were two unadvertised bonuses:a 64gb memory card, and a clear soft case
I have used the phone for about a week as I write this with no significant issues
Transferring the information from the old S7 to the A50 was quick and simple using the recommended Samsung method
The SIM card also went over with no problem
Many reviews noted the fingerprint reader to be temperamental and initially I did find it a bit awkward but after getting used to it, and putting Liquid Armor on the screen, it is now not bad
Takes a bit longer than the reader on the S7 but is OK
I was concerned the phone would be too big, but it fits nicely in my hand and the ability to move app buttons to the bottom of the screen eliminates the reach issue
Performance is about what I was expecting for its price and specifications, and battery life is also as I was expecting based on its size and reviews
I am disappointed that Samsung elected to drop the LED notification light
The S7 and my BlackBerrys before had that feature and I am really missing it
My only concern is that the phone is a Latin America version and the warranty card is for that area, not Canada
I am going to follow up on that aspect
I should note that after the initial language setting to UK English there has been no occurrence of Spanish
So far a great phone for the price, I would recommend it to anyone looking for a midrange Android phone

Good phone with working recognition feature but I had to replace the 64 GB memory stick.

One problem I had was the 64 GB memory card that came with the device stopped working after about a month, and I had to switch to one from my old phone after I tried a few fixes that didnt work
Good budget phone, glass is impossible easy to scratch.
Very great all-rounder for a fraction of flagship series, but;Glass is very scratchable, my pants and fingernails were mystifyingly enough to need a repair

s This is my first Amazon review
First smartphone and I'm blown away!
I've had this phone for just over a month now and I love it
I went from a Nokia E71 to this phone so there was a huge size difference but the typing experience on the BlackBerry is actually better

At first it was clumsy (why did they make such a small space bar?) but I have now gotten used to it and I'm actually faster due to the fact that BlackBerry inserts periods, spaces, and capitalizes for you
So Basically I just pound out a message and don't think about punctuation
In addition, once you get used to the predictive typing options (just flick your thumb up to choose a word) it gets even faster

It has actually learned a few of the words I use more often, and when it isn't learning fast enough (I'm in the military and use far to many acronyms) they have the option to manually add words/acronyms/whatever

If I'm in an area that has 4G (maybe 30% of the time I use the phone) I can just say whatever I want to the BlackBerry Assistant and the servers at BlackBerry are able to figure out what I'm saying 99% of the time
Pretty cool feature
not used much
The keyboard:great except for the small space bar
Same material or something?I don't know but it makes correcting typing much easier!It is also AWESOME to scroll with
I don't even touch the screen
The main reason I bought this phone was because I wanted a physical keyboard and I like to read a ton of news/information
This phone is wonderful for those purposes
One of my favorites is the Reader options on websites
I cannot stress enough how wonderful this option of the native browser is

You know how you bring up news stories/reviews/virtually anything on the internet and it is full of ads?As soon as the page starts loading just presstheR button and BlackBerry's browser sifts through it in about 2 seconds and provides you the ACTUAL story (no ads, it has never screwed up this, not once) and any relevant pictures

The web browsing is good on just about every site I have been to, super fast, true to the website, and if I run into compatibility problems I just tell the BlackBerry browser to run the site as a computer (Full Site)
I don't know if this is common to all phones nowadays, but it truly displays the site as if you were on a desktop
And that's perfectly okay due to the screen size/readability!Apps
I quickly learned how helpful, and unhelpful, apps can be
The Passport has Blackberry World as well as the Amazon App Store installed from the factory
The Blackberry store has a decent mix of apps
The Amazon store has a lot more though
I also side-loaded SNAP so I have access to the Google Play store
Google Play has a ton of apps, some of them useful, some of them just want your information
The main thing that matters to me is that the Passport allows you to control what information you share in apps
It is the only phone/company that does this
This is HUGE!Any apps you download from Blackberry can be totally controlled by you
From the other two
not so much
Accept all terms and conditions or else

The funny thing is that some of the most popular apps do exist in Blackberry World, but the same app downloaded in another app store will not have the ability to control them and the information they steal from you
I am a working professional and still attend classes
I was hoping to use this phone while I have downtime to get some school work done online
This can't happen because my school uses Flash for their online textbook (I never knew this before)
The Passport DOES have Flash, but it is an older version that doesn't work with my school's textbook
I have read that that it is not Blackberry's fault, Adobe quit updating their mobile software, or whatever, after a certain point
But Blackberry is not alone!Apple doesn't like Flash either
And it seems the industry is moving towards HTML 5
which the Passport DOES support
So that's great for the future
But for now
no convenient school :(It is compatible with all Microsoft Office programs though
The software that comes with it is pretty good
Especially for Excel
I have yet to find a Word program that can truthfully display a computer screen onto the phone in true proportions
but this screen comes very close
I'd say 4/5 of the time it's true to the computer screen for Word
It's only in titles and other crazy large print that it doesn't know what to do with it
I held my own US Passport up to it and it matches almost exactly
It's also pretty thin
So I don't have any size complaints
I'm 5'10, 190lbs, and I wear normal jeans
Nothing tight or loose
just normal people clothes

Complicating matters is the fact that I'm an Apple loyalist - I have owned but one PC in my life, the one exception to multiple MacBooks, Powerbooks, and desktop Macs

I realized that what I use my phone most for fit perfectly into the realm of the Passport:- E-mail

Processing power is outstanding for all functions…the phone flies through swipes and clicks

Another advantage is that I now leave Wi-Fi on all the time…something I didn’t do with my previous phones due to battery drain

Blackberry Passport.  It's the phone you need!
